title: Abbreviated Mental Test (AMT-10)
description: Assesses mental impairment in elderly patients through 10 questions evaluating various aspects of cognitive function including memory, attention, and orientation

parameters.name: time_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly states the time to the nearest hour

parameters.name: year_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly states the current year

parameters.name: address_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly states their home address or current location

parameters.name: recognition_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly recognizes two people (doctor, nurse, family member, etc.)

parameters.name: dob_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly states their date of birth (day and month sufficient)

parameters.name: wwi_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly states the year World War I started (1914)

parameters.name: leader_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly names the current monarch/president/prime minister

parameters.name: counting_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly counts backwards from 20 to 1

parameters.name: recall_correct
parameters.description: Patient correctly recalls the address given earlier (e.g., '42 West Street')

result.name: amt_score
result.description: AMT-10 total score out of 10 points

ranges.interpretation: Score of 8-10 points indicates normal cognitive function. No significant cognitive impairment detected.
Score of 6-7 points suggests mild cognitive impairment. Further assessment may be warranted to determine underlying causes.
Score of 5 or less suggests significant cognitive impairment, including possible delirium or dementia. Further comprehensive assessment and workup are recommended.

references: Hodkinson HM. Evaluation of a mental test score for assessment of mental impairment in the elderly. Age Ageing. 1972;1(4):233-238.

Pendlebury ST, Klaus SP, Mather M, de Brito M, Wharton RM. Routine cognitive screening in older patients admitted to acute medicine: abbreviated mental test score (AMTS) and subjective memory complaint versus Montreal Cognitive Assessment and IQCODE. Age and Ageing. 2015;44(6):1000-1005.
Jackson TA, Naqvi SH, Sheehan B. Screening for dementia in general hospital inpatients: a systematic review and meta-analysis of available instruments. Age and Ageing. 2013;42(6):689-695.
formula: AMT-10 Score = Sum of correct answers (0-10 points)
notes: Originally designed for use in elderly patients for rapid cognitive assessment
Score <8 suggests cognitive impairment; score <6 suggests delirium or dementia
Cultural and language adaptations may be necessary in diverse populations
Some questions may need updating for contemporary relevance (e.g., WWI dates, monarch names)
Used as part of the Nottingham Hip Fracture Score for prognostic assessment
Should be interpreted alongside clinical history and other assessments
Not suitable for patients with severe hearing, speech impairments, or language barriers
